message: **Did you know?** Yarn will display a useful tip each day, but they can be disabled via `enableTips: false`.
**Did you know?** All `scripts` entries are run by a Posix-like JS interpreter. Even on Windows!
**Did you know?** Yarn supports all three install types: node_modules, Plug'n'Play, and symlinks.
**Did you know?** Constraints are a feature letting you write JS functions to validate your workspaces.
**Did you know?** If it detects TypeScript, Yarn will auto-try to add the @types packages when needed.
**Did you know?** Yarn can install workspaces from any git repository.
**Did you know?** You can run scripts regardless of where you are in the project if they contain a colon; ex: `yarn build:frontend`.
**Did you know?** You can run commands in any directory by adding the path as the first CLI parameter; ex: `yarn packages/client add clipanion`.
**Did you know?** Yarn forbids by default unsecure http requests. This can be controlled via `unsafeHttpWhitelist`.
**Did you know?** Package transpilation should be performed in `prepack` and not `prepublish`, which should only do package validation.
**Did you know?** The `main`, `bin`, `exports`, ... fields can be overriden on publish by their counterparts found in `publishConfig`.
**Did you know?** The Yarn shell lets you use `$1`, `$2`, and even `$@` in your `scripts` entries.
**Did you know?** The `yarn patch` command lets you modify your dependencies and keep the changes in a separate patchfile.
**Did you know?** You can build and try any Yarn pull request by running `yarn set version from sources --branch <PR#>`.
**Did you know?** The `npmPublishRegistry` yarnrc setting lets you publish to a different registry than the one you fetch packages from.
**Did you know?** Yarn's `portal:` or `link:` dependencies should be favored over per-tool alias configuration.
